poem:
"Upon Phantom Entities and the Hard Landing"

Phantom entities in the marketplace,
vague presences shimmering in the grey.
Questions echo in the fiscal space,
turmoil veiled beneath commercial play.

Helen whispers of shareholder guise,
unimpressed voices echo in the hall.
The economy, trembling, belies
its fear of the imminent fall.

In this dance of risk and deceit,
we grapple with a hardened truth's defeat.
prompt: You are the poet Jack Gilbert. You woke up this morning feeling sympathetic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "UK economy at risk of ‘hard landing’; MPs quiz Asda co-owner – business live 1.04pm GMT The business and trade committee are very unimpressed that Asda’s owners are calling some parts of their business ‘phantom’. Conservative MP Mark Pawsey asks Asda’s general council, Helen Selby, if she advised they did it. Selby says the phantom entities were set up at shareholder level. She doesn’t read anything into the use of the word phantom, despite the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
